ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: performing quantitative analysis in linguistics
R Skills and an understanding of how linguistic data can be analyzed in R
Learned R and basic linguistic analysis
Statistical analysis in regards to linguistics
Became very skilled in R
Using R for linguistic data analysis
Learned how to use R for tasks related specifically to linguistics. Learned some about the linguistic background, too, because some students had never taken a linguistics course before.
This class was my first linguistics class and it gave me a basic understanding of the field and allowed me to appreciate language
I learned new functions I can use in R. I also was given a basic introduction to linguistics.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: strengths: great content. great exercises. the course overall is a good overview for linguistics students looking to get hands-on practice in doing statistics. weaknesses: maybe it's just me but the lectures are kind of easy to get lost in
Interesting content, but more focus on worksheets and discussions and less time on lectures would be useful.

This course is great because it teaches quantitative skills in a small seminar, which is more conducive to learning than large lectures. It's also great that it doesn't have prerequisites in statistics, as I had no statistical background. However, the lack of linguistics prerequisite meant we had to spend some time catching people up on the topics being discussed. Everyone in the class was coming from a different educational background which made learning together difficult even though it was interesting to have a diverse group - so I'm not sure how this could be solved for. I also loved that this course had no exams, unlike most quantitative courses.
Strengths: very thorough introduction and interesting for all levels of experience due to incorporation of linguistics Weaknesses: lectures can sometimes be a bit dry and hard to understand
Less R commands more stats

You do come out of the class knowing how to interpret and analyze data in linguistics studies, but it helps a LOT to have some background in R or coding in general I didnt, and the learning curve was very steep. Class wasnt particularly helpful in teaching your how to use R as well because the commands and function arguments werent actually explained, it was more just a demonstration of pre-coded lines. A good number of people in the class were S&DS majors too taking it as an elective, just something to note. The linguistic theory behind some studies we looked at were briefly explained, just a quick run through of basic linguistics concepts nothing new if youve taken any linguistics before. Most helpful thing of the course was the comments on homework assignments

Strengths of the course include the exercises, which helped to solidify how to use the R commands correctly. A weakness of the course was the somewhat dull lectures. It felt like most of the stuff could be looked up or read ahead of time, and class could have been spent just doing exercises or talking about linguistics.
Honestly Professor Sanker is really great and super kind. The class is well organized and both she and Parker (our TA) really wants us to succeed
The course is basically a small lecture with occasional pop quizzes and in class exercises. I would have preferred if visual aids accompanied the lectures, such as PowerPoint presentations.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! If you're interested in linguistics or data science or both, give it a shot! You'll learn lots about both fields alone and their intersection, even if you've never had experience in either.
Yes, I think this is the perfect course for people interested in both linguistics and hard skills like R, but it's also a great course to take for stats people and non-stats linguists.
Yes
Yes if you want to learn how to think about linguistics from a stats point of view
I would recommend this class to anyone who likes linguistics and wants to learn a bit more about how the analyses are done.
Absolutely! It was great to have this class as an introduction to linguistics!
I would recommend this course to anyone looking for a fun and light stats elective.
